I remember when America, when I was little, we never used to be that kind of country, right, we didn't f*ck with nobody. Now, we be f*ckin' with people in El Salvador and sh*t. How we gonna lose? Thirty-five people in El Salvador.

An African man asked us, when we was talkin', he said, "What language do you speak at home?" You know, we looked at each other, "What? English?" "Everybody speak English, but, what language you speak when you're home?" One of the brothers looked at him and said, "Jive?"

[Comments after returning from a trip to Africa]
You know, its just such a nice feeling. I know how white people feel in America, now. Relaxed. That's right! 'Cause you hear like, eh, a police car comin', you know it ain't comin' after your ass. Why, you just, "I wish they'd keep that god damn noise down." Cause I hear it, man, I wake up, automatically start thinkin' about sh*t I did. "Eh, what the muthaf*cker knows? Sh*t! Let me see." Till they go by, "Sh*t, oh, it ain't me."
In Africa, though, I had that feeling, man, I was just comfortable. I knew the police wasn't gonna be f*ckin' with me. Unless the government changed overnight.
I don't know where in the f*ck I came from over there.

Every place I go though, man, everybody I meet, they want to come here, right. They want to come to America. I mean, all the three countries I've been to. I don't want to sound like I've been everywhere, you know. Three. You start talkin' to them and they start talkin' about America. And it makes your dick hard for America. They do. They finish talkin' and you be sayin' "Sh*t, I got to get my ass back there! We got all that sh*t in America?"

'Cause, like here we're all in this theater, we get along real good. Until we go outside. Then the sh*t change. So, we just must be some crazy muthaf*ckers, or somethin'. 'Cause we can get along real great for a moment, then, we can't. So, that's insanity.

I haven't done any drugs now, it's been, seven months. And that's a lot! That's a lot for me. You know, 'cause I done, I think I done drugs since I was like - fourteen. You know what I mean? Off and on... when I was nineteen I started doin' it really heavy. Right. This is the first time, I think, in my life I feel like this. Bein' sober, and then being off drugs too, its a real strange feelin'.

If I had some drugs and sh*t, I wouldn't give a f*ck. But, then I wouldn't, I'd come off stage, I still wouldn't give a f*ck. Then, by the time you're fifty, a lot of no givin' a f*ck, you miss part of your life. "So, what happened to your life?" "I didn't give a f*ck."
